Organs/Tissues: Human intestine (barrier epithelium), optionally with endothelium underneath
Physiological/Pathological: Both – normal epithelial barrier or inflamed/disease (IBD) depending on setup
Cell Source: Caco-2 line or primary human intestinal epithelial cells ± immune/stromal cells (fibroblasts, etc.)
Stromal Cells: Yes, if user co-cultures fibroblasts or myofibroblasts
Circulating Immune: Yes, can flow immune cells (PBMCs, T-cells) in a perfused endothelial channel
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Single organ chip by default, but can be linked to other organ chips
Air-Liquid Interface: Yes (upper channel air, lower channel perfused) if desired
Extracellular Matrix: Yes (membrane coating or 3D matrix on the epithelial side)
3D Scaffold: Possible—hydrogel or collagen if forming a 3D epithelium on the membrane
Notable Features: Transparent glass chip, re-sealable, high-quality imaging; dynamic flow for intestinal barrier studies
Plate/Format (Throughput): Individual microfluidic chip + holder (low throughput; ~1 condition/chip)
Max Culture Duration: Days to weeks with continuous flow
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, excellent optical clarity for real-time microscopy
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, collect outlet perfusate for secreted factors/toxins
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Yes, can disassemble to harvest cells from membrane
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, membrane-based histology or 3D scaffold retrieval
Readouts - TEER: Not integrated, but external electrode methods possible
Dead Volume: Low channel volume, minimized with short tubing
Perfused: Yes, external pump drives flow across epithelium
Gas Mix Controlled: Incubator environment only (no built-in gas exchange)
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Yes, can alter flow rates, media composition, add immune cells in real-time
model_availability: Product only (chip + membranes + holder); no direct assay service

Organs/Tissues: Human liver acinus (hepatocytes, endothelium, stellate, Kupffer cells)
Physiological/Pathological: Both – normal hepatic function or disease (NAFLD, fibrosis) via user-defined conditions
Cell Source: Primary human hepatocytes ± non-parenchymal cells (endothelial, stellate, Kupffer); iPSC-derived also feasible
Circulating Immune: Yes, immune cells can be perfused through vascular channel
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Yes, can link to other organ chips (gut, kidney) externally
Air-Liquid Interface: No, typically submerged flow for hepatic function
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, membrane coating or 3D hydrogel within channel
3D Scaffold: Yes, user can embed liver cells in collagen or place them on porous membrane
Notable Features: Zonation possible via O2 gradient, glass-based chip prevents compound absorption
Plate/Format (Throughput): Single microfluidic chip, low throughput (1 condition/chip). Multiple chips in parallel possible
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, glass chip for confocal/fluorescence imaging
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, effluent for albumin, urea, CYP metabolites, drug clearance
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Yes, chip can open, membrane/tissue can be removed
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, entire 3D structure or membrane for histology/immunostaining
Readouts - TEER: Not standard, but possible with custom electrodes
Dead Volume: Low volume microchannels, short tubing recommended
Perfused: Yes, external pump or gravity flow provides continuous media
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Yes, dynamic flow changes, drug additions, immune cell injection on the fly
model_availability: Product only (re-sealable chip + holder + membranes) with custom design if needed

Organs/Tissues: Two or more organ chips fluidically connected (e.g. intestinal barrier + hepatic metabolism)
Physiological/Pathological: Both – physiological cross-organ interactions or combined disease states (gut inflammation affecting liver)
Cell Source: Each chip can have primary or iPSC-derived cells for that organ, plus immune/stromal elements
Multiple Cell Types: Yes, each organ chip can host multiple cell types
Stromal Cells: Yes, fibroblasts/stromal cells in each relevant organ compartment
Tissue-resident Immune: Yes (Kupffer in liver, lamina propria macrophages in gut, etc.)
Circulating Immune: Yes, can flow immune cells across connected channels
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Yes, fluidic linking for multi-organ synergy (drug metabolism, toxin synergy, etc.)
Air-Liquid Interface: If one chip (lung/gut) is set up with ALI, otherwise typically liquid flow
Extracellular Matrix: Yes in each chip’s membrane or 3D matrix region
3D Scaffold: Yes, 3D constructs in both (or multiple) organ channels
Notable Features: Systemic interaction modeling; can observe drug’s path from gut to liver, etc.
Plate/Format (Throughput): Multiple re-sealable chips with external tubing; low throughput, high complexity
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, each chip has glass-based imaging windows
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, sample from each chip’s outlet or combined circuit
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Yes, remove membranes or gels from each chip
Readouts - TEER: No built-in; can be adapted in gut chip
Dead Volume: Moderate (summing each chip’s channels + connecting tubing)
Perfused: Yes, linking flow among organ chips
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Yes, can alter flow paths, media composition, immune cell injection
model_availability: Product only (chips + holders + membranes), user sets up multi-chip circuit
